comment.author: 29492435@N02
comment._content: It is thought salmon fishermen have been building bridges to the island for over 350 years. It has taken many forms over the years. In the 1970s it had only one handrail and large gaps between the slats. A new bridge, tested up to ten tonnes, was built with the help of local climbers and abseilers in 2000. Another was built in 2004 and offered visitors and fishermen alike a much safer passage to the island. The current wire rope and Douglas fir bridge was made by Heyn Construction in Belfast and raised early in 2008 at a cost of over £16,000.[3] Although no one has fallen off the bridge, there have been many instances where visitors, unable to face the walk back across the bridge, have had to be taken off the island by boat

comment.author: 80413507@N08
comment._content: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carrick-a-Rede_Rope_Bridge#History This article dates the single hand rail to the 1970's so it is going to be difficult to date this photo

comment.author: 80413507@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/tj_q8] it would definitely have been a minimalist approach. Rope would have been expensive and you are correct, one hand on the rail the other arm carrying salmon nets and salmon.

comment.author: 29492435@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/47290943@N03] Everybody and his dog is into the to the death-defying lark up here, even in Derry/Londonderry !! Limavady derives it's name from the Irish meaning "Leim an Mhadaidh" meaning leap of the dog, arising from the legendary leap over the River Roe by a dog owned by the O'Cahan Clan to warn the Chieftains of an enemy ambush. The jump took place from the Dogleap Bridge, in the Roe Valley Country Park, where the site of O'Cahan's castle once stood. O'Cahan's Rock, an 80ft high riverside precipice within the park used for abseiling, is also associated with the legend of the O'Cahans; legend relates that an O'Cahan horseman evaded his pursuers through leaping from O'Cahan's Rock to safety on the other side of the river. It is said that the horse's hoof print is still visable on the rock. www.flickr.com/photos/ryanharkin/5654319093/

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/13073434@N03] It was being pushed as a tourist attraction at the Belfast Exhibition in 1895 (Belfast News-Letter, May 5th 1895)
NORTHERN COUNTIES RAILWAY COMPANY This company also has an interesting collection of views at their stand, which closely adjoins that of the Down Railway Company. There are photographs of most of the principal places on the Northern circular tour, which should be of interest to intending holiday makers in Ireland. The fine waterfall and bridge at Glenariff excellently brought out in photographic form, and the collection includes the Carrick a Rede rope bridge on the north Antrim coast, the Giant's Causeway, Garron Point, Dunluce Castle, Portrush, and other special features of the Northern tourist resorts.

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/shanekillen] That hoof print legend seems fairly widespread.
In Cois leice between Mullranny and Curraun in Mayo there are "devils hoof prints" on the bare rock. As per the legend when St Patrick banished snakes and the devil off Croagh Patrick across Clewbay the devil landed there leaving the hoof prints.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
In a review of a biography of a John MacGregor, who is described as "lawyer, philanthropist, athlete, preacher, traveller, author, volunteer, contraversialist", The Graphic of October 6th 1894 quotes the following passage:
In company of six choice companions, MacGregor, then in his seventeenth year ... went to see the bridge at Carrick-a-Rede (in the north of Ireland), connecting a little island in the sea with the high cliffs, and formed of two ropes carrying a plank about seventy feet long and only a few inches wide, high in mid-air over the dashing foam. As they drew near they were pressed by a crowd of men and women to take one for a guide ...
The incident ends with MacGregor having a fight on the bridge.
... his blood was up, and standing on the narrow plank with certain destruction before him if he over-balanced and fell, he buffeted the big bully with his knees, boxed him with his hands, kicked him with his feet, until at last he rose and scrambled over on all fours, followed by MacGregor
Ignoring possible exaggeration over the years in the telling and retelling of the tale or in the interests of the book being a good read, and ignoring any possible slackness on the part of the biographer in checking dates and facts, MacGregor was born in January 1825, and his 17th year when this incident is said to have taken place would be Jan 24th 1841 to Jan 24th 1842. So even as early as that, the bridge seems to have been somewhere to visit and where locals could augment their income by acting as guides (even if their customer relations skills seem to have been wanting if, like MacGregor, you declined their services). Edit: the full text of the book is here. The Carrick a Rede incident is in chapter II

comment.author: 66151649@N02
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Here kids, here's a nice shinny penny/shilling (or what have you)! Go stand on the one sided rope bridge and hope it doesn't get windy enough to either loop the bridge around  or to push you off the side with no handrail... It looks dangerous. 

Based on these photos, I must conclude that the Irish are either incredibly fearless or incredibly foolhardy (and I mean that in the nicest way possible) to have built such daring bridges... Wow.

"It spans 20 metres (66 ft) and is 30 metres (98 ft) above the rocks below.[2] The bridge is mainly a tourist attraction and is owned and maintained by the National Trust. In 2009 it had 247,000 visitors. " Almost 70 feet long and 100 feet above the rocks below? Holy cr#p. Although I'd probably be stupid enough to pay the fee to cross it if I was there myself, but wow...

comment.author: 66151649@N02
comment._content: And yes we have the metric system in Canada, but it's kind of a joke. We use American measurements for some things, metric for others. Learn meters in school, then get to the lumber yard one day and have to figure out stuff in feet and inches. Aye.

In the USA, "Mythbusters" Adam and Jamie sometimes use the old Imperial measurements Stones and Yards.
14 lb = 1 Stone.
3 feet = 1 Yard.
